article:
A 'plumb-bob' or a 'plummet' is a weight, usually with a pointed tip on the
bottom, that is suspended from a string and used as a vertical reference line,
or 'plumb-line'.

The instrument has been used since at least the time of ancient Egypt Denys A. Stocks.
[http://books.google.com/books?id=oLDuHvQODoIC&pg=PA180 Experiments in Egyptian
archaeology: stoneworking technology in ancient Egypt]. Routledge; 2003. ISBN
978-0-415-30664-5. p. 180. to ensure that constructions are "", or
vertical. It is also used in surveying to establish the nadir with respect to
gravity of a point in space. They are used with a variety of instruments
(including levels, theodolites, and steel tapes) to set the instrument exactly
over a fixed survey marker, or to transcribe positions onto the ground for
placing a marker.
